text:
A general view southward from Duane Street, between Park Row and Centre Street, and showing the City Hall Zone, when it was known as Printing House Square. This view is slightly further westward than No. 1, and also shows Broadway on the farther side of City Hall Park. On the right appears the new Hall of Records (under construction) with the City Hall Building just beyond. Note demolition of the Fire Engine Co. No. 7, Hook and Ladder No. 1, which stood at the northeasterly corner of City Hall Park.

About 1902.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
title: Manhattan: Duane Street - Park Row

text:
A general view southward from Duane Street, between Park Row (left) and Centre Street (right) and showing in the foreground buildings on the triangular plot that now, (1937) is occupied by the Municipal Building. Shown from left to right are the N. Y. Herald (bearing statue) Brooklyn Bridge Station, Pulitzer (N. Y. World), Staats-Zeitung, N. Y. Times (under renovation), Park Row, United States Post Office, and the City Hall Buildings. The spire shown in the foreground is of St. Andrews R. C. Church which still stands today.

About 1902.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
title: Manhattan: Duane Street - Park Row

text:
Foley Square, northward, from the Municipal Building, showing this civic center prior to improvement. Thru the center runs Centre Street (cartracks). On the left and right respectively are Lafayette and Park Streets. The solitary one story clinical (narcotic addictions) faces on Worth Street. Columbus Park is in the right background. This open area, the Collect Pond site, has not as yet been improved because of shifting sands. Engineering advances will enable this danger to be avoided. Incidentally this was the scene of the first work relief program in New York; the Pond being filled in by men that were thrown out of work by the embargo declared by President Jefferson in 1812. He, fearing naval complications with Great Britain closed the port.

Gift of E. M. Jenks

1916-7
title: Manhattan: Foley Square - Municipal building.

text:

This open area, the Collect Pond site, has not as yet been improved because of shifting sands. Engineering advances will enable this danger to be avoided. Incidentally this was the scene of the first work relief program in New York; the Pond being filled in by men that were thrown out of work by the embargo declared by President Jefferson in 1812. title: Manhattan: Foley Square - 58th Street

text:
Foley Square (unofficially called Court House Square), east side, between Pearl (right) and Worth (left) Streets, showing the N.Y. County Court House under construction. These 4 views (taken at the same time) show that part of the building that will form the front. On the right appears the old Board of Health Building.
July 1923.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

title: Manhattan: Foley Square - Pearl Street

text:
Foley Square, east side, between Pearl and Worth Streets, showing the New York County Court House under construction. This set of 4 views shows the Pearl and Baxter Street sides. The fenced area in the foreground is the south side of Worth Street, east of Centre Street. On the right appears the old Board of Health Building. The entrance will be through the unfinished frame work shown on the right. Centre Street at this point forms the east side of Foley Square.
July 1923.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

title: Manhattan: Foley Square - Pearl Street

text:
Lafayette Street, north from Duane Street (where tracks are seen), to and including Leonard Street, showing the New York Edison Co. plant and office building on the west side of the street extending from Duane to Pearl Streets. Also shown are Nos. 520 to 514 Pearl Street (right foreground), east from and including Lafayette, to but not including Centre Streets. These houses and those extending on the east side of Lafayette north to Worth Street were later demolished to make way for a small park. In the centre background is visible part of the New York Life Insurance Co. Building (with clock-tower) occupying the block from Catherine Lane to Leonard Street.

December 1925.

Brown Brothers.

Lafayette Street (right), north from and including Reade, to but not including Pearl Streets, showing the 21-story Court Square Building (No. 2 Lafayette Street) from Reade to Duane Streets. Also shown (left) is Reade Street, west from Lafayette Street with a portion of the Hall of Records visible in the foreground. The New York Edison Co. plant and office building is shown extending from Duane to Pearl Streets (side wall with sign on it), and on Duane Street, north side, from Lafayette to Elm Streets.

1926.

Photograph submitted by the Court Square Building Inc.

Lafayette Street, west side, (right), north from and including Reade, to and including Leonard Streets, showing work in progress on the foundation for the new 21-story Court Square Building, adjoining the 10-story Jones Building (only the rear of which is shown), from Reade to Duane Streets. Also shown is the New York Edison Co. office building and plant, from Duane to Pearl Streets. In the left foreground is seen Reade Street, north side, west from Lafayette, to and including Elm Streets. The New York Life Insurance Co. Building (with clock-tower) is visible in the right background occupying the block from Catherine Lane to Leonard Street. 1926.

Photograph Submitted by the Court Square Building Inc.

Centre Street, east side, north from Pearl Street. Buildings shown across the background, are on the north side of Leonard Street, east from Centre to Baxter Streets. The 1-story building in the foreground, is used by the Child Welfare Board, and is on the north side of Worth Street, east of Centre Street. Eventually this will form the site of the N.Y. State Office Building.

September 24, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

SLIDE # 241, 248.

About 1935

Gift of Dr. Michael Wishengrad, A.R.F.S.

Foley Square: The New York County Court House on the east side of Centre Street, between Pearl and Worth Streets, as viewed northward from the steps of the Federal Courts Bldg. At the extreme left appears a portion of the New York State Bldg.

June 12, 1938.

P. L. Sperr

Foley Square, easterly side, north from Duane, across Pearl, to Worth Streets, showing respectively, The Federal Courts Bldg., the New York County Court House and the New York State Bldg. all facing on what technically is Centre Street.

Views 2 and 3 emphasize the New York County Court House and are viewed eastward from Elm Street (the westerly boundary of the square) which in its self is really a continuation of Lafayette Street.

All of these structures are built upon and around what in early days was Collect Pond and where in 1796, John Fitch tried his new steamboat under the observation of Chancellor Livingston and other prominent New Yorkers. Where Centre and Leonard Streets intersect today it had a depth of 60 feet. During the English and French conflict, President Jefferson (1807) ordered an embargo on all shipping and New York suffered. To alleviate same, individuals were set to work to fill in this pond and morass and thereby set a precedent for public work relief. A drainage canal was cut thru in 1809 which later became Canal Street.

Propositions for the use of the area as a Park were introduced as early as 1789, though naught came of them and it remained a dreary vacant area awaiting modern scientific engineering. Their main difficulty was not water but quicksands and most of these buildings have what is called a floating foundation.

P. L. Sperr

June 12, 1938.
Views 1, 2 and 3
title: Manhattan: Foley Square - Pearl Street

text:
Foley Square, easterly side, north from Duane, across Pearl, to Worth Streets, showing respectively, The Federal Courts Bldg., the New York County Court House and the New York State Bldg. all facing on what technically is Centre Street.

Views 2 and 3 emphasize the New York County Court House and are viewed eastward from Elm Street (the westerly boundary of the square) which in its self is really a continuation of Lafayette Street.

All of these structures are built upon and around what in early days was Collect Pond and where in 1796, John Fitch tried his new steamboat under the observation of Chancellor Livingston and other prominent New Yorkers. Where Centre and Leonard Streets intersect today it had a depth of 60 feet. During the English and French conflict, President Jefferson (1807) ordered an embargo on all shipping and New York suffered. To alleviate same, individuals were set to work to fill in this pond and morass and thereby set a precedent for public work relief. A drainage canal was cut thru in 1809 which later became Canal Street.

Propositions for the use of the area as a Park were introduced as early as 1789, though naught came of them and it remained a dreary vacant area awaiting modern scientific engineering. Their main difficulty was not water but quicksands and most of these buildings have what is called a floating foundation.

P. L. Sperr

June 12, 1938.
Views 1, 2 and 3
